The Discourse to Dhaniya
“I am Pakudha Kaccāyana,
(says Dhaniya the cowherd)
who lives on the shore of the ocean,

analyzed: channā kuṭi ā hi taḥ gini
translated: my hut is covered, my fire is lit,
if you wish, rain down, god!”
“I am free from anger, free from hatred,
(says the Fortunate One)

analyzed: anu tīre mahiyā ika ratti vāso
translated: who lives for one night on the shore of the ocean,
my hut is open, my fire is out,
if you wish, rain down, god!”
“There are no Andhaka mosquitoes,
(says Dhaniya the cowherd)
the cows graze in the grass-covered valleys,
they can endure the fallen rain,
if you wish, rain down, god!”
“The rope is tied, the well is well-dug,
(says the Fortunate One)
having crossed over, gone to the other shore, having stilled the flood,
there is no use for the rope,
if you wish, rain down, god!”
“My cow is obedient, not lazy,
(says Dhaniya the cowherd)
for a long time she has been pleasant to live with,
I do not hear any evil from her,
If you wish, then rain down, O cloud.”
“My mind is well-tamed, well-controlled,
(said the Blessed One)
Well-developed for a long time, well-trained;
But I find no evil in myself,
If you wish, then rain down, O cloud.”
“I am my own master, my own lord,
(said the wealthy cowherd)
My sons are healthy and well;
I hear no evil of them,
If you wish, then rain down, O cloud.”
“I am not a servant of anyone,
(said the Blessed One)
I wander free from bondage in the world;
I have no need for wages,
If you wish, then rain down, O cloud.”
“I have cows, I have milk cows,

analyzed: iti dhaniyaḥ gopaḥ  godharaṇiyo paveṇiyo pi atthi
translated: (said the wealthy cowherd)🔽I have bullocks, I have heifers;
I have bulls, the lords of the cows,
If you wish, then rain down, O cloud.”
“I have no cows, I have no milk cows,

analyzed: iti bhagavān  godharaṇiyo paveṇiyo pi natthi
translated: (said the Blessed One)🔽I have no bullocks, I have no heifers;
I have no bulls, the lords of the cows,
If you wish, then rain down, O cloud.”
“The pegs are driven in, the dam is not breached,
(Thus spoke Dhaniya the cowherd)

analyzed: dāmā muñja mayā navā su saṇṭhānā
translated: The new ropes are made of muñja grass and well-fashioned;

analyzed: na hi sakkhinti dhenu pāpi chettu
translated: The cowherds cannot break them,
If you wish, then rain down, O cloud.”
“Like a bull breaking its bonds,
(Thus spoke the Blessed One)
The elephant has broken the rotten creeper;
I will not return to lie in a womb,
If you wish, then rain down, O cloud.”
Filling the low and the high,
The great cloud rained just then;
Having heard the rain of the cloud,
Dhaniya spoke this meaning:

original: “Lābhā vata no anappakā,🔽Ye mayaṁ bhagavantaṁ addasāma;
analyzed: lābhā vata naḥ anappakā  ye mayam bhagavantam addasāma
translated: “Indeed, we have gained much,🔽That we have seen the Blessed One;
We go for refuge to you, O Visionary One,

analyzed: satthā naḥ hohi tuvam mahā muni
translated: Be our teacher, O Great Sage.
The cowherdess and I, the obedient one,
We will practice the spiritual life under the Well-Gone One;
Having gone beyond birth and death,
We will make an end to suffering.”
“One who has children rejoices in her children,
(Thus spoke Māra the Evil One)
The one who owns cattle rejoices with the cattle,
For attachments are a man’s joy.

original: Na hi so nandati yo nirūpadhi”.
analyzed: na hi saḥ nandati yaḥ nirūpadhi
translated: He does not rejoice who is without attachments.”
“One who has children grieves for the children,
(said the Blessed One)
The one who owns cattle grieves for the cattle,
For attachments are a man’s grief.

original: Na hi so socati yo nirūpadhī”ti.
analyzed: na hi saḥ socati yaḥ nirūpadhī iti
translated: He does not grieve who is without attachments.”
The Second Portion for Repeating is finished.
